results.title: Street XRays
results.brief_description:
Drawing on the NSW Police Department’s photographic archive, Street X-Rays interprets approximately sixty crime scenes from the 1950s, to evoke the power of the continuing life of the past in our ordinary, everyday places.

The police images are placed beside contemporary footage recorded in the same location, from the same camera position. Each screen holds two moments in time, two disparate attempts to interrogate a location. Texts from police records and the artist’s enigmatic narrative prompts punctuate this essentially visual dialogue. The effects of time linger in each scene and across the entire imaginative space of this half-historical/half-mythical city that is evoked in the installation space.

I’ve tried to conjure a place that’s haunted by persistent little pulses of history. I hope viewers feel as if they’ve wandered into a vaguely familiar ‘otherworld’ that’s being buffeted by a kind of ‘spirit weather’ - Ross Gibson.

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: Telling tales
results.brief_description:
Telling Tales are real stories told and produced by people with a disability and those who are disadvantaged.

Telling Tales challenges the ‘norms’ as often represented by mainstream film with first person accounts that provide a real opportunity to be seen and heard. The stories explore personal journeys of identity, displacement, relationships, longing and memory.

Telling Tales was produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.creator_credit: Antony Riddell and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. A stop-motion animated short film where the characters repeatedly ask ‘Are you alright, mate?’.

results.title: The Naked Artist
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Robert Rosmarin
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.
Robert Rosmarin talks of the sometimes chaotic family-life of his childhood, reaching a climax with a tragic car accident which claimed the life of his mother. He talks about his on and off relationship with art, including participating in Spencer Tunick’s iconic crowd nude photographs taken on Princes Bridge in Melbourne.

results.title: My Life with Epilepsy
results.brief_description: Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop ‘Telling Tales’. Jodi tells of her family history with epilepsy and her personal journey as the condition began to affect her life.
